original_title: Sri Lanka meets most IMF commitments, transparency platform not done
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka has met most of the commitment in an International Monetary Fund program by March but failed in one, indicator, Verité Research, a Colombo based think tank said in a statement.
An IMF program typically has prior actions before it is approved which has to be met.
After it is approved there are mandatory, performance criteria (PCs) which may lead to the suspension of the program if not met.
A series of reforms called structural benchmarks also has to be met. In this program some reforms are part of the World Bank and ADB policy lending, which are also disbursed as prior actions.
For 2023, about 900 million dollars are to be disbursed by the World Bank and ADB on prior actions, outside of an IMF drawdown.
Partly due to the possible delay in the structural reforms IMF money has been allowed to be used in the budget.
Verité said the the Failed Commitment related to an online transparency platform.

“This platform is expected to publish, on a semi-annual basis, information related to (i) all significant public procurement contracts, (ii) a list of all firms receiving tax exemptions through the Board of Investment, and (iii) a list of individuals and firms receiving tax exemptions on luxury vehicle imports,” the statement said.
“It was due by 1 March 2023, but not met even by the end of that month.”
